title: Crude oil imports from Russia plunge on payments
summary: New Delhi: India’s crude oil imports from its largest supplier Russia plunged in December to their lowest since January 2023, as six tankers carrying Sokol-grade oil could not deliver due to payment issues amid tightening sanctions, according to data intelligence company Kpler.
content:
New Delhi: India’s crude oil imports from its largest supplier Russia plunged in December to their lowest since January 2023, as six tankers carrying Sokol-grade oil could not deliver due to payment issues amid tightening sanctions, according to data intelligence company Kpler.

After rising to an all time record of 2.15 million barrels a day in May, oil imports from Russia fluctuated downwards, experiencing a sharp decline between November and December to 1.48 million barrel

title: Xi pledges to strengthen economic recovery
summary: BEIJING: Chinese president Xi Jinping pledges to strengthen economic momentum and deliver on job creation, acknowledging some companies and citizens had a difficult 2023 in a rare admission of headwinds the country is facing.
content:
Pivotal period: People having their dinner at a restaurant as a screen broadcasts Xi delivering his New Year’s speech. Fresh geopolitical risks are anticipated from elections in the United States and Taiwan this year. — AFP

BEIJING: Chinese president Xi Jinping pledges to strengthen economic momentum and deliver on job creation, acknowledging some companies and citizens had a difficult 2023 in a rare admission of headwinds the country is facing.

title: Avaland in for stronger earnings momentum
summary: PETALING JAYA: Avaland Bhd is expected to have stronger earnings momentum going into financial year ending Dec 31, 2024 (FY24), backed by the right products and strategies for its upcoming projects and land banking plans.
content:
PETALING JAYA: Avaland Bhd is expected to have stronger earnings momentum going into financial year ending Dec 31, 2024 (FY24), backed by the right products and strategies for its upcoming projects and land banking plans.

RHB Research said Avaland’s property sales are likely to reach between RM500mil and RM700mil in FY23 and FY24, respectively.

Its unbilled sales are predicted to increase to a peak of RM867mil in the nine months of FY23 as compared to RM720mil i

title: BYD posts record 4Q sales to challenge Tesla
summary: SHANGHAI: Chinese automaker BYD Co sold 526,409 fully electric vehicles (EVs) in the fourth quarter, meaning Tesla Inc will need a record showing to maintain its No. 1 status when it unveils its sales figures today.

title: French new
car sales up
in December
summary: PARIS: French new car registrations rose 14.5% in December, capping a year of market growth, says the PFA auto association.
content:
Stocks of new cars are parked in a lot, at Walon France automobile transport company in Hordain, northern France, May 26, 2020. REUTERS/Pascal Rossignol/File Photo

PARIS: French new car registrations rose 14.5% in December, capping a year of market growth, says the PFA auto association.

Sales for the full year rose 16.1% to 1.77 million vehicles.

Volkswagen AG, the third-biggest seller in France, reported a jump of 19.5% in its registrations in De

title: US stocks likely to
stay on upward trend
summary: NEW YORK: The US stock market’s hefty gains in 2023 could provide a lift for equities this year, if history is any guide.
content:
Massive growth: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in New York. A banner year for the S&P 500 ended with an annual gain of just over 24%. The benchmark index also stood near its first record closing high in about two years. — Bloomberg

NEW YORK: The US stock market’s hefty gains in 2023 could provide a lift for equities this year, if history is any guide.

title: The 2024 economy could top 2023’s achievements
summary: THE American consumer ended 2023 with a burst of economic good cheer, relatively speaking. (Which is to say: happier than they were a few months ago, not as happy as they were a few years ago.)
content:
Low supply: A pedestrian in the Brickell neighborhood of Miami, Florida. Lower rates should also help address the acute lack of inventory in the housing market. — Bloomberg

THE American consumer ended 2023 with a burst of economic good cheer, relatively speaking. (Which is to say: happier than they were a few months ago, not as happy as they were a few years ago.)

title: ExxonMobil exits West                       Qurna 1 oilfield
summary: NEW YORK: US energy giant ExxonMobil Corp has formally exited the West Qurna 1 oilfield in southern Iraq and handed over its operations to PetroChina as a lead contractor, says a deputy oil minister.
content:
People walking past an Exxon station in Washington. — AFP

NEW YORK: US energy giant ExxonMobil Corp has formally exited the West Qurna 1 oilfield in southern Iraq and handed over its operations to PetroChina as a lead contractor, says a deputy oil minister.

Senior Iraqi oil officials met with executives from ExxonMobil, PetroChina and Basra Oil Co on Monday at the West Qurna 1 field near Basra to mark Exxon’s complete exit and the handover of i

title: Global interest                pushes K-food exports
summary: SEOUL: South Korea posts a new record high in food exports, driven by the steadily increasing global interest in South Korean culture and strategic initiatives by food companies that have rigorously promoted their products overseas.
content:
Exotic flavours: A food vendor preparing pancakes at a stall in Gwangjang Market, Seoul. The total export value of agricultural and food products reached US$9bil by the end of the third week of December, according to government data. — Bloomberg

title: Russia faces mighty obstacle amid western LNG sanctions
summary: SINGAPORE: US sanctions pose a major obstacle to Russia’s plans to increase exports of seaborne liquefied natural gas (LNG) to offset the decline in pipeline exports to Europe, analysts say, as expectations mount of delays to a flagship project.
content:
FILE PHOTO: A view shows the Port of Murmansk

SINGAPORE: US sanctions pose a major obstacle to Russia’s plans to increase exports of seaborne liquefied natural gas (LNG) to offset the decline in pipeline exports to Europe, analysts say, as expectations mount of delays to a flagship project.

Russia, the world’s fourth-largest LNG producer after the United States, Qatar and Australia, aims to increase its share of the global market to around a fift

title: Maersk pauses Red Sea traffic after Houthi container ship attack
summary: COPENHAGEN: Iranian-backed Houthi militants attacked a Maersk container vessel with missiles and small boats, prompting the company to pause all sailing through the Red Sea for 48 hours, according to Maersk.

The container ship Laura Maersk, commissioned by shipping giant Maersk with an engine that can burn traditional heavy fuel oil or green methanol, at port in Copenhagen, Sept, 14, 2023. (Betina Garcia/The New York Times)

title: Ringgit toflex its
muscles
summary: PETALING JAYA: The ringgit is set to continue benefiting from investors selling the US dollar and this will provide Bank Negara the flexibility to reassess its monetary policy this year.
content:
PETALING JAYA: The ringgit is set to continue benefiting from investors selling the US dollar and this will provide Bank Negara the flexibility to reassess its monetary policy this year.

The ringgit’s appreciation against the world’s reserve currency since last October is poised to continue as investors unwind their positions out of the greenback in anticipation of a pivot in interest rate policy by the US Federal Reserve (Fed).

Currency analysts expect the move

content:

title: KLCC Holdings sets                its sights on healthcare
summary: KUALA LUMPUR: KLCC (Holdings) Sdn Bhd has set out growth strategies for 2024 that will include it venturing into the healthcare sector.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR: KLCC (Holdings) Sdn Bhd has set out growth strategies for 2024 that will include it venturing into the healthcare sector.

Group chief executive officer Datuk Md Shah Mahmood said this was something the group is exploring without setting a time frame for its implementation.

“We are looking at developing a full-fledged sector which will incorporate a hospital, senior living and the infrastructure that comes with it.

title: Country’s imports of food products still high
summary: PETALING JAYA: Malaysia’s food industry has gone through another year of trade deficits in 2022, as imports of food products far exceeded the country’s exports to other markets.
content:
A rice harvester in action at a padi field in Kampung Pada Telela in Perlis.

PETALING JAYA: Malaysia’s food industry has gone through another year of trade deficits in 2022, as imports of food products far exceeded the country’s exports to other markets.

In 2022, the food trade deficit increased to RM31bil, on the back of RM75.6bil in imports and exports of RM44.6bil.

According to the Malaysia Trade Statistic Review 2023 (MTSR 2023) , the country

title: Energy-poor Bangladesh and the country’s transition obligations
summary: THE 2015 Paris Agreement intends to curb the increase in the global average temperature to well below two degrees Celsius.
content:
THE 2015 Paris Agreement intends to curb the increase in the global average temperature to well below two degrees Celsius.

Bangladesh, being a tier-three country with low carbon dioxide (CO2) emission, limited land, and climate vulnerability, has no obligations in this regard.

In terms of total emissions, as of 2016, China, the United States, and India held the top three positions, emitting 50% of CO2.

Bangladesh held the 48th position in total emissions,

Asia spike by 53%

title: December sales of SUVs soar, smaller cars skid
summary: BENGALURU: Sales of sports utility vehicles (SUVs) rose in December, while small-car sales fell despite high discounts, data from Indian automakers show.
content:
Cars are seen parked at Maruti Suzuki's plant at Manesar, in the northern state of Haryana, India, August 11, 2019. Picture taken August 11, 2019. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis/File Photo

BENGALURU: Sales of sports utility vehicles (SUVs) rose in December, while small-car sales fell despite high discounts, data from Indian automakers show.

While entry-level vehicles remain a millstone around automobile makers’ necks, they have benefited from the sale

title: US Treasuries post
first gain since 2020 as pivot gets traction
summary: NEW YORK: The US treasury market posts its first annual gain since 2020 as slowing growth and inflation bolstered views that the Federal Reserve’s (Fed) campaign of interest rate increases is likely over.
content:
NEW YORK: The US treasury market posts its first annual gain since 2020 as slowing growth and inflation bolstered views that the Federal Reserve’s (Fed) campaign of interest rate increases is likely over.

The result stands in sharp contrast to the market’s performance for most of 2023.

Benchmark yields were propelled to multiyear highs in October by the prospect that monetary policy would remain tight indefinitely.

Growth in the supply of treasury debt als

title: Sungei Bagan to take over Kuchai Development
summary: PETALING JAYA: Sungei Bagan Rubber Co (Malaya) Bhd has proposed to take over all assets and liabilities of Kuchai Development Bhd (KDB) for RM275.47mil.
content: PETALING JAYA: Sungei Bagan Rubber Co (Malaya) Bhd has proposed to take over all assets and liabilities of Kuchai Development Bhd

title: No Malaysians involved in Japan earthquake, says Wisma Putra
summary: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Malaysia said no Malaysians have been reported to be involved or affected by the earthquake that struck the central and west coasts of Japan on Monday, as of the most recent report.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Jan 1): The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Malaysia said no Malaysians have been reported to be involved or affected by the earthquake that struck the central and west coasts of Japan on Monday, as of the most recent report.

In a statement late on Monday, the ministry said it, via the Embassy of Malaysia in Tokyo, is closely monitoring developments in the aftermath of the earthquake.

The quake, with a preliminary magnitude of 7.6, triggered tsunami

title: Public should not be concerned about Padu as data regulated under existing laws, says MDEC chairman
summary: Malaysians should not be concerned about data collected under the Central Database Hub (Padu) as it is regulated by several existing laws.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Jan 1): Malaysians should not be concerned about data collected under the Central Database Hub (Padu) as it is regulated by several existing laws.

Malaysian Digital Economy Corp (MDEC) chairman Syed Ibrahim Syed Noh said the Omnibus Bill will also be tabled by the government, and it will be able to prevent any abuse by irresponsible parties.

“So there won’t be a situation where the data will be misused [in] scams and such. To me, it cannot hap

title: PBB to present recommendations to EC on re-delineation exercise in Sarawak, says Abang Johari
summary: Parti Pesaka Bumiputera Bersatu (PBB) will present recommendations to the Election Commission (EC) regarding a possible re-delineation exercise of Sarawak’s electoral boundaries.
content:
KUCHING (Jan 1): Parti Pesaka Bumiputera Bersatu (PBB) will present recommendations to the Election Commission (EC) regarding a possible re-delineation exercise of Sarawak’s electoral boundaries.

Its president Tan Sri Abang Johari Tun Openg said the party has a special committee responsible for overseeing re-delineation issues. 

“For now, the matter (re-delineation) is still under study. We will only make recommendations because the fina

title: Malaysians flock to Hatyai this festive season, contributing two billion baht to local economy
summary: Visitors from Malaysia to Hatyai, the vibrant southern Thai city, doubled to 20,000 daily during the Christmas and year-end holiday season, contributing more than two billion baht (RM267.23 million) to the local economy in two weeks before the year ended.
content:
BANGKOK (Jan 1): Visitors from Malaysia to Hatyai, the vibrant southern Thai city, doubled to 20,000 daily during the Christmas and year-end holiday season, contributing more than two billion baht (RM267.23 million) to the local economy in two weeks before the year ended.

Hatyai Songkhla Hotel Association president Sitthipong Sitthiphataraprabha said Hatyai’s appeal lies on its combination of delectable and diverse food choices, easy accessibility, and affordable hotel options drew Malaysians in drov

title: Zaliha to address Kuala Lumpur's legacy issues
summary: Minister in the Prime Minister's Department (Federal Territories) Dr Zaliha Mustafa wants to address legacy issues, and improve the quality of life for city folks.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Jan 1): Minister in the Prime Minister's Department (Federal Territories) Dr Zaliha Mustafa wants to address legacy issues, and improve the quality of life for city folks. 

Issues such as cleanliness and safety around Masjid Jamek and the River of Life area, homelessness and the influx of undocumented foreign nationals in Jalan Silang and several main roads in the capital will be looked into, she said. 

In a Facebook p

title: Perak leaves it to AirAsia to resume Ipoh-Langkawi flight
summary: Any decision to resume the Ipoh-Langkawi flight route from the Sultan Azlan Shah Airport (LTSAS) here lies entirely with AirAsia, the Perak state government said on Monday.
content:
IPOH (Jan 1): Any decision to resume the Ipoh-Langkawi flight route from the Sultan Azlan Shah Airport (LTSAS) here lies entirely with AirAsia, the Perak state government said on Monday.

State Tourism, Industry, Investment and Corridor Development Committee chairman Loh Sze Yee said based on reports, several matters need to be resolved before the service is resumed.

“There are many factors including demand, ticket prices, the existing aircraft stock, time constr

title: Malaysia's GDP at 4.0pct in 2023 but momentum to slow in new year: AHAM Capital
summary: KUALA LUMPUR: Malaysia's full-year gross domestic product (GDP) growth is expected to average around four percent in 2023, supported by strong private consumption, according to AHAM Capital Asset Management. However, economic momentum may start to dwindle in 2024 amid a recalibration ...
content:
KUALA LUMPUR: Malaysia's full-year gross domestic product (GDP) growth is expected to average around four percent in 2023, supported by strong private consumption, according to AHAM Capital Asset Management. 

However, economic momentum may start to dwindle in 2024 amid a recalibration in spending patterns among consumers due to subsidy rationalisation. 

"An increase in the sales and services tax (SST) rate to eight per cent could exert further pressure on spending as consumers refrain from high-value purchases," AHAM

title: Saudi sovereign wealth fund splashes cash in 2023 - report shows
summary: LONDON: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund accounted for about a quarter of the almost $124 billion spent by sovereign wealth funds worldwide last year, a report published on Jan. 1 showed.PIF's whopping $31.5 billion spend in 2023 compared with $123.8 billion for ...
content:
LONDON: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund accounted for about a quarter of the almost $124 billion spent by sovereign wealth funds worldwide last year, a report published on Jan. 1 showed.

PIF's whopping $31.5 billion spend in 2023 compared with $123.8 billion for all sovereign wealth funds, based on a preliminary annual report from industry specialist Global SWF, which tracks the world's sovereign investment funds.

The strong rally last year in global stocks helped to swell the assets managed by the so

title: Malaysian consumers remain positive about economic outlook — UOB study
summary: While many Malaysian consumers are planning to maintain or decrease their expenses due to concerns about rising inflation, they are more optimistic about the economic situation compared to the region, with about two in three respondents expecting themselves to be financially better off by June 2024, according to UOB’s Asean Consumer Sentiment Study (ACSS) 2023.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Jan 1): While many Malaysian consumers are planning to maintain or decrease their expenses due to concerns about rising inflation, they are more optimistic about the economic situation compared to the region, with about two in three respondents expecting themselves to be financially better off by June 2024, according to UOB’s Asean Consumer Sentiment Study (ACSS) 2023.

Although three in four respondents felt that Malaysia will likely face an economic downturn within the next six to 12 months, thi

title: How Malaysians can save on trips during new year holidays
summary: KUALA LUMPUR: E-hailing service Maxim has revealed insights on how fare dynamics are set to change, offering users tips to secure faster and more cost-effective rides during the festive period.According to Maxim specialists, in the period from Dec 24 to ...
content:
KUALA LUMPUR: E-hailing service Maxim has revealed insights on how fare dynamics are set to change, offering users tips to secure faster and more cost-effective rides during the festive period.

According to Maxim specialists, in the period from Dec 24 to Jan 2, the demand for trips increases by more than 45 per cent.

At the same time, during hours of high demand, the price of a trip can be 1.5 to two times higher than the usual.

"This is due to the inclusion of an additional coefficient that increases the cost of th

title: First-time homebuyers' demand to remain strong in 2024: Mah Sing founder
summary: KUALA LUMPUR: Mah Sing Group Bhd founder and group managing director Tan Sri Leong Hoy Kum expects first-time homebuyers' demand for housing to remain strong.This is given that Bank Negara Malaysia has projected the country's economic growth to ...
content:
KUALA LUMPUR: Mah Sing Group Bhd founder and group managing director Tan Sri Leong Hoy Kum expects first-time homebuyers' demand for housing to remain strong.

This is given that Bank Negara Malaysia has projected the country's economic growth to be firm at between 4.0 and 5.0 per cent in 2024.

The RM10 billion Housing Credit Guarantee Scheme, which is included in the 2024 Budget, will contribute to first-time homebuyers' increased access to home ownership, Leong said.

As such, Mah Sing expects continu

title: EC to review re-delineation of electoral boundaries only in Sarawak, says chairman
summary: The Election Commission (EC) has no plans to carry out a re-delineation of electoral boundaries for the states of Malaya and Sabah, as the Federal Constitution only allows the process to happen every eight years, says EC chairman Tan Sri Abdul Ghani Salleh.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Jan 1): The Election Commission (EC) has no plans to carry out a re-delineation of electoral boundaries for the states of Malaya and Sabah, as the Federal Constitution only allows the process to happen every eight years, says EC chairman Tan Sri Abdul Ghani Salleh.

The last time the country did so was in 2018, hence the re-delineation of electoral boundaries can only be done in 2026.

As for Sarawak, however, Abdul Ghani said the EC is considering a
thumbnail_url: https://assets.theedgemarkets.com/20221020_PEO_PRESS CONFERENCE SPR_SB  (2)EC chairman Tan Sri Abdul Ghani Salleh_20240101112429_theedgemalaysia.jpg

title: Police: 598,635 road accidents recorded in 2023
summary: A total of 598,635 road accidents were reported nationwide from Jan 1 to Dec 30 last year, said Bukit Aman Traffic Investigation and Enforcement Department (JSPT) deputy director Datuk Mohd Nasri Omar.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Jan 1): A total of 598,635 road accidents were reported nationwide from Jan 1 to Dec 30 last year, said Bukit Aman Traffic Investigation and Enforcement Department (JSPT) deputy director Datuk Mohd Nasri Omar.

He said that of the total, 12,417 accidents involved death.

“A total of 2,331 cases involved serious accidents; 28,511 involved minor crashes. The rest only involved damage to vehicles,” he told reporters after c
thumbnail_url: https://assets.theedgemarkets.com/20210508_PEO_SJR MCO 3.0 KOTA DARUL EHSAN 7_SY _Mohd Suhaimi Mohamed Yusuf_20231209142940_theedgemalaysia_0.jpg

title: Number of flood evacuees in three states drops to 1,483
summary: The number of flood evacuees in three states continued to record a downward trend to 1,483 people housed in 15 temporary relief centres as of 6am on Monday, compared with 1,675 people in 16 centres on Sunday night.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Jan 1): The number of flood evacuees in three states continued to record a downward trend to 1,483 people housed in 15 temporary relief centres as of 6am on Monday, compared with 1,675 people in 16 centres on Sunday night.

According to the latest report issued by the National Disaster Management Agency's National Disaster Command Centre, those evacuated to relief centres in Kelantan continued to drop to 1,395 people accommodated in 11 relief centres on Monday morning

title: Deputy education minister encourages use of face masks at schools
summary: The standard operating procedure (SOP) related to curbing the spread of Covid-19 in schools and educational institutions, issued in April last year by the Ministry of Education (MOE), is still applicable, said Deputy Education Minister Wong Kah Woh.
content:
TAIPING (Jan 1): The standard operating procedure (SOP) related to curbing the spread of Covid-19 in schools and educational institutions, issued in April last year by the Ministry of Education (MOE), is still applicable, said Deputy Education Minister Wong Kah Woh.

Wong said that the SOP involves encouraging the use of face masks for teachers and students, in addition to school staff having to do self-tests if they have symptoms and always maintaining personal hygiene.

title: Can Asean realistically embark on dedollarisation path, or is it merely a storm in a teacup?
summary: NAVIGATING the current geopolitical currency tensions in Asean prompts a critical question: Can the region realistically embark on a path of dedollarisation?The complexities of the global economic stage, coupled with the ongoing geopolitical tussles, present substantial hurdles for any ...
content:
NAVIGATING the current geopolitical currency tensions in Asean prompts a critical question: Can the region realistically embark on a path of dedollarisation?

The complexities of the global economic stage, coupled with the ongoing geopolitical tussles, present substantial hurdles for any ambitious move away from the dollar.

The Asean nations, facing a delicate balancing act, must weigh the benefits of potential independence from the dollar against the risks of heightened currency tensions and economic uncertainties.

title: Poverty after retirement?
summary: KUALA LUMPUR: Will Malaysia soon face a retirement crisis, given that almost 40 per cent of its citizens do not have a retirement plan?Only 4.0 per cent of Malaysians could afford retirement, according to the Employees Provident Fund (EPF) calculations from ...
content:
KUALA LUMPUR: Will Malaysia soon face a retirement crisis, given that almost 40 per cent of its citizens do not have a retirement plan?

Only 4.0 per cent of Malaysians could afford retirement, according to the Employees Provident Fund (EPF) calculations from the previous year.

Increased expense of living in today's world and withdrawals of substantial portion of their savings from the EPF during the pandemic had caused some members to experience poverty even before they can retire, a market insider said.

"This

title: Sabah eyes 4pc growth this year
summary: KUALA LUMPUR: Sabah finance ministry expects an overall economic growth rate of about 4.0 per cent next year, supported by strong domestic consumption, increased investments and ongoing recovery of key sectors.State finance minister Datuk Seri Panglima Masidi Manjun said he ...
content:
KUALA LUMPUR: Sabah finance ministry expects an overall economic growth rate of about 4.0 per cent next year, supported by strong domestic consumption, increased investments and ongoing recovery of key sectors.

State finance minister Datuk Seri Panglima Masidi Manjun said he is bullish about 2024 as its economy continues to recover and grow.

"Despite a challenging 2023, where the state saw a significant contraction in its trade balance due to decreased export values of major commodities like petroleum, crude oil (CO) and

title: Malaysians usher in New Year 2024 with religious activities, family outings
summary: New Year 2024 was ushered in moderately throughout the country after the government decided not to hold any official celebrations as a sign of solidarity with Palestinians suffering at the hands of the Israeli regime as well as out of respect to the flood victims in several states.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR (Dec 31): New Year 2024 was ushered in moderately throughout the country after the government decided not to hold any official celebrations as a sign of solidarity with Palestinians suffering at the hands of the Israeli regime as well as out of respect to the flood victims in several states.

Checks by Bernama in Kuala Lumpur revealed that in addition to the unofficial celebrations by private parties and companies at several locations, including The Exchange TRX and Kuala Lumpur Tower
thumbnail_url: https://assets.theedgemarkets.com/New Year celebration at The Exchange TRX, Kuala Lumpur_20240101084115_bernama.jpg

title: M’sia secures top spot in global Islamic indicator
summary: KUALA LUMPUR: Malaysia has once again secured the top position in the Global Islamic Economy Indicator (GIEI) for the 10th consecutive year, according to the Halal Development Corp Bhd (HDC).
content:
HDC chairman Khairul Azwan Harun said the milestone underscores the sustained progress within Malaysia’s halal ecosystem since the establishment of HDC in 2006.

KUALA LUMPUR: Malaysia has once again secured the top position in the Global Islamic Economy Indicator (GIEI) for the 10th consecutive year, according to the Halal Development Corp Bhd (HDC).

“The 2023 rankings place Malaysia at the forefront, followed closely by Saudi Arabia, Indonesia, and the
